commentBody:
"Oh, you're studying slang?"
"Well, we argot-ing to."

(I found that one in the jargon bin.)
Easy enough, but still scratching my head over those generational expressions. Had no idea what they meant. So…okay puzzle but not really enjoyable.

RIGHT ON, Gary and Doug!  

(I’m practicing using the slang the puzzle thinks I should.)

Okay, enough of that. Gotta SPLIT.
Groovy, phat, on fleek, and bussin’.
Fun Sunday. Hope y’all have a great day! Thanks, Gary & Doug. Looking forward to your next collaboration.
Couldn’t help noticing the crossing of two capital sins at 53D, 67A.

Far out! I dig the theme and had a gas solving. 

Peace and love.
Never got the theme.too abstruse for me. Solved as a theme less. Spume was new to me

SNACKCOUNTER, like, gag me with a spoon... eww! Totally grody to the max! I checked it out and don't dispute its existence but again I say, eww! 

It reminds me of a time someone said, "Aw, that baby's so cute I just want to get a spoon and scoop her up." Eww!! Stop! 

Okay, okay, aside from my extreme aversion to the idea of considering people to be edible treats, I enjoyed the puzzle! Went very smoothly along with a simple but cute theme! 

I actually finished in half my average time to make up for how long Saturday's fun but hard puzzle took me. Har! 

However, I don't understand IRR at 13D—can anyone, or everyone, enlighten me?
At 104A saw [Promoting…] immediately thought SHoPPING (as in …around} Chekhov saved me.
Wondering if I was the only one who found out BIG KAHUNA also fit as head honcho? Fixed it pretty quickly but AYEAYE threw me off longer. Yeah, read the clue next time lol! Fun puzzle!
What a tough weekend. 29 minute solve, and just in time for Game 2. 99 Days on the Streak, which means, barring the unthinkable tomorrow, I'm looking at 100+ Days
Totes legit.
Considering that the eldest Gen Z members were 3 years old when Eminem released Stan, I'm pretty sure Millennials are responsible for that one.

I found this a perfect Sunday puzzle!  Quite witty, with ideal complexity.  I felt like I had a good sparring session, but nothing too exhausting.  I only needed one little cheat, I didn't Google, but wikied Asa Butterfield's page to see what he starred in 2013.    This required a little reading, so it's a tiny cheat.  (I did see that movie a while back ago, but it didn't motivate me enough to look up the actors.)

Thank you!

The best thing about this puzzle was that it made me glow with victory snaps  every time I teased out a fill.  The worst thing was that I had two deadly mistakes that took a frustrating ten minutes to find (wasted a lot of time admiring the clever, funny themers and kinky fills), but at last it was done.

I remember your last collaboration Doug and Gary, and it was a winner too.  This was a fitting wind-up of really, really good week-end puzzles.  Thanks to everyone who made it happen.

Ever time I see the name, Gary Larson, I can’t help but think of The Far Side. An alternative title for this puzzle could have been The Far Out Side, which also carries its own ambiguity. 

Very well done. Can’t wait for the next installment

A very pleasant puzzle for a Sunday, quite clever and enjoyable. The top half went a little fast but got more interesting as I went down. I liked the KENDOLL clue and the cross of ENVY and AVARICE—I wish they had tied those together more. Had a laugh at the clue for AMBIGUITY. Wondering if anyone else but HeathieJ and I (see comments below) really got the willies from the SNACKCOUNTER clue? I am usually the last person to get all PC and feel like something is inappropriate, but this one seemed in bad taste even to me. If it was a really great clue or the only possible option, then maybe,  but it seemed kind of meh. And in the meantime, although of course “snacks” is a legitimate slang term for “hotties”, and some people talk that way, do we need to be reminded of it? The clue came off to me as trivializing or normalizing it. If you think I’m being too prudish about this please let me know because it’s not my usual reaction, but I’m thinking if I feel that way a lot of others will to even more strongly.
My favorite puzzle ever! I want to erase the answers from my memory so I can solve this puzzle again.Like a delicious meal with friends.

Unrelated to the Sunday puzzle... I was today years old when I realized there's a monthly "bonus puzzle" online only? 😲 Anyone else not know this? Or am I the last to find out?

I have a pretty old version of the app but I don't remember seeing these in the app and these monthly bonus puzzles go back to 1997 🤯

Meh. Flew through this one. A few pretty good clues, but most were fairly obvious. The theme didn't appeal to me. Collector's item was probably the cleverest clue. I always heard that liquid gold in cooking was aquafaba, or the water from canned chick peas. Same idea as pasta water (starchy liquid), I guess.

Gary and Doug, without fail, play havoc with my thought process.  For some reason, I have a great deal of difficulty with either of their puzzle clues.  But to team them up on me?  Not fair!  :)  Heck of a challenging puzzle for me, needed some help to finish, but it was a workout.
ENISLE feels like a stretch

Very cool, super hot, totally rad puzzle, and a blast to solve. Thank you, gents! And someone's gotta post it for those who don'tknow it... (The Who with "My generation") – https://youtu.be/qN5zw04WxCc?si=W8aZmDhlkGLAPIMx A kickin' week to all!
Fun theme. I need someone to explain 112D. How are TIPS “Tax code issues”?  Not clicking for me.
This puzzle was skibidi Ohio!
Clung to fOOTIES for way too long but finally got the happy music and was able to 32A high above Baffin Bay.
I was rather disappointed to see that both pieces of "Gen Z" terminology date back to the aughts (or earlier!).  We are not, it seems, talkin' bout my generation.
What is a "squee" entry?

Thanks Caitlin for the 72D link. 

not sure I’m happy with AMBIGUITY as opposed to Ambiguous as a description of a headline but I’m guessing we’ve been warned today to not be the 5D of pendants. 

As others have noted top half flew by much faster than the lower. A nice Sunday morning overall. 

Thanks to the constructors and editors
Smooth clockwise fill. Quickly entered SAS instead of KLM, a mistake I wouldn’t have made 40 years ago when I was working for TWA. One flyspeck and then off to sleep.

how often do the crossword and the mini share fill?
8A in the latter and 70D today.
initially harshed my buzz but now im kinda felling groovy about it.

I'm not sure I will be finishing the puzzle.

The NW corner was Monday-easy. However, the rest of the puzzle is proving almost impenetrable for me. Some 30 minutes into the solve, the grid was largely empty. Feeling lost, I checked it. Sure enough, many of my guesses turned out to be wrong. I had to reveal the ungettable - for me - crossing of PA_R and I_R. I'm not really getting the theme, either. 

The fun factor of the solve at the moment is zero for me. It's not likely to improve. Better to call it quits than spoil my Sunday morning by persevering, I think.
ENISLE is a new word for me, thank you NYT
Great crossword! Clever. I tried to put myself in each of the generations but that didn't help much. Once I solved the clue I understood the relevance. Thank you.
Why is Kids Make Nutritious Meals an Ambiguity?

Arrgh, failed by one square. No clue what the intersection of 13D and 21A is. Pro instead of Pee really messed me up for a while at the bottom, especially since I needed the crossers to get enisle. I never would have guessed that that was even a word.
Can anyone make sense of 117d  being PEE? Still trying to get my head around that one

What is ATT (QB stat)? Google is not helping. Grr, another 3-letter sports term! I am trying to remember these, but the football ones are tougher.

That is for two links, Caitlin. The YORKIE one is fun, and the crash blossoms one is hilarious. Laugh out loud stuff.
Speaking of boomers, FAB FOUR crossing ARLO.
Stanlaurel might be my favorite clue answer ever.
Not seeing anyone else mention 63D. As a non-follower of sports and far from Gen Z, I had PRO THESPIAN entered until the bitter end. 🤦🏾

I usually find Sundays fairly easy, but today was quite hard. 
I thought it was ypsilon.

I don't know the slang. I first heard US slang and the term "baby boomer" when I was in New York City 1974-75, and boomer wasn't referred to in the UK for many years. 

Not that many of us "boomers" used American slang. I was aware of "split" "far out" and "right on" occasionally. 

CHIS? Please help.
Lefty-loosey? Is that really a thing or crossword only?

CAP TOSS ritual - something done at the beginning of a baseball/football/hockey match?

These big crosswords are a nice Sunday ritual for me, very enjoyable.

Puzzles have often been sparked before by generational patois as answers, but I don’t remember seeing an entire theme based on it, and what a splendid and original idea.  A theme that makes solvers of all ages feel seen!

While it’s lovely to base a theme on words that echo generations, it’s a step up to hide them in common phrases that use them in their more-common non-generational meanings.  

Bravo, gentlemen!

Beyond the theme, there were answers I loved: NIBBLE, AVARICE, FILCH, SCUFF, and the roll-off-the-tongue AMBIGUITY.  

There was also a clue, [Green opening], that mightily misdirected me, where my face screwed up as I wondered, “What could that be besides ECO?”  

And there were sweet serendipities.  A quartet of dog references: STAY, SITS, FLEAS, YORKIE.  The rhyming ATRIA and ACACIA.  No to mention SEE / PEE / LEE / the clue [Wee] / and wannabe KNEE.  

A merry mix in the box today, which I thoroughly enjoyed.  Thank you, Doug and Gary!

I enjoyed this slangy, fast moving puzzle.  Some of the slang I knew and some I didn’t, but I  was happy to learn some usages with which I was unfamiliar.  With crosses and a little logic, even the unknowns were easy to suss out.  Fun enough to be a worthy Sunday after two tough jewels on Friday and Saturday.

STANLAUREL and SHIPPINGLANES were the cleverest themers for me.

I was so certain that 46A was NOd instead of NOM that I didn’t check the crosses, which would have alerted me that NAdE is not a [Handle]. Even with that it seemed to go fast.

The theme was silly in a good way and I especially giggled at RIGHTONTIME. I’ll take a little lame humor in my crossword any day.
The bottom left was messy for me. Shouldn’t it be SHoPPINGLANES? But oRINA didn’t sound like a Russian name…

That was a very clever theme that somehow left me feeling a bit meh (which generation is that?) 
I think it’s probably because 99% of those phrases meant absolutely nothing to me as a late Boomer. The whole naming generation thing is a fairly new concept to me. Still, I see the work that went into this and, as always, I respect and appreciate the constructors ability.

Re comments further down regarding the SNACK COUNTER phrase. Yes, I too found it a bit icky, without getting too worked up about it.

Jonathan Swift suggests braising in pasta water. Somehow, I think Aphrodite had more important issues on her mind than Greek spelling conventions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R-P_ru0doJI (Yum! Snacks!)

This was a breeze until I got hopelessly stuck on the first half of 116A.  Didn’t help that this was my first encounter with 101D, and CEO and USB for 117 and 118 down seemed so obvious.  Wasn’t until I changed 117d to pee that it all clicked.
But once they rescued me and I came back to Pittsburgh, I was an exisle.

ENISLE??????????????

Solved unaided in 31 minutes, but will take the rest of the day to get that one out of my head.

Otherwise, nice Sunday puzzle.

I came to commiserate about the theme but all I see is crying foul about a rare but perfectly legitimate word. 

Those complaining about ENISLE should remember that a big part of being a crossword solver is learning new words!
really loving all the proper names today

Fairly breezy for a Sunday, as I finished around 20% faster than my average. I was surprised when I got the star, however, as there were a couple I was unsure about. Regarding ENISLE…I don’t recall ever seeing the word before, although it’s appeared in the crossword 85 times, 25 of those in the “modern era.” The last time it was in the puzzle before today was Thursday, November 5, 2015, which is a couple years before I started doing the XW in 2018, after I retired.

To be honest, when I looked up its definition, given our current state of chaos, it actually sounds like a pleasant prospect, assuming certain people are with me, as well as a few good books. 

One curious fact about the word…apparently its peak usage, at least since 1800, was around 1990. As it seems a tad archaic, I’m curious what was going on 35 years ago…

That was a fun solve. The southeast corner was particularly challenging. 
I'm on a 54 day streak now and I swear I must have seen TSA clued in a dozen different creative ways.

Had TInS for 112D.  Taxpayer identification numbers are issued by the IRS, confusing cluing as there's nothing in the clue that indicates that it should be TIPS (I guess that's the point) unless you know that vaulted meant LEAPT. My brain  couldn't get there after I was committed to TInS.
I found this to be kind of a boring slog, unfortunately.

Took forever to find my fOOTIES/BOOTIES error.  So many names in the SW that I wasn't sure of, I spent a loooong time there running the alphabet in different squares in between running laps through every answer in the puzzle.  I never did like RUf, but fOOTIES I thought was fine, especially since my house was just sold, and fOOTIES seemed fine for whatever those things are called that were by my front door for a few weeks.  Persistence paid off; happy to get the win even if it took 80% longer than average to do so.

Well, as John Donne never said, no man is ENISLE.

Yup, still living rent-free in my head. Must let it go ...
Could some please let me know what does IRR mean in the context of bargain bins?

[What a maroon! (Pre-software Crosswordese)]


WOW! A CURRENT APPEARANCE OF ENISLE!
The only problem with this puzzle is that it's too short. I wanted it to go much, much longer. Great job guys!
With this NE corner I'm just going to assume this is a "lookups or trivia mastery required" puzzle. Really now, three trivia proper names crossed with a pun?

Maybe it was too soon after yesterday's puzzle?

Letting two Gods of CrossWorld sit together in back, where they came up with this notion of *common phrase, plus *newer, slang usage, PLUS *punny clue...all piled one on top of the other.
And this on top of a dark and stormy night (sideways rain, thunder and lightning, high winds, frightened kitty-cat seeking comfort)...okay, I guess we can't blame that last one of Gary (not THAT Gary) and Doug.  
But:
STREET ROD, fellas?
So where’s the guy who always asks if this is the same Gary Larson who drew the Far Side cartoons?
I enjoyed the theme and the puzzle overall! Definitely learnt some new words and US-isms today.

* 12 minutes under par for the crossword
* Queen bee
* Wordle in 4
* Purple first in Connections, no mistakes
* Spangram first in Strands
* Sudoku sweep
* Mini in a minute

Not keen on Pips, but I love a lazy Sunday. On to football. Go Bills.

It's always embarrassing when boomers try on younger generations' slang. Please stop. Mid-life crisis, maybe?

I did a double-take when I finished sleepwalking through the puzzle and saw DDR at the end. East Germany? Oh, Dance Dance Revolution.

What? No Silent Generation?


I am speaking up.

I never thought I would see DDR as an answer. A flood of memories washed over me. My best friend’s family had all of the greats when it came to gaming consoles and accessories. Including DDR. Played in between ‘Ocarina of Time’ meltdowns.

Oof, the last few squares in the upper-right corner took me an extra ~15 minutes — I’ve never heard of a “street rod” or a comedian named Gabe Kaplan, I haven’t seen Ender’s Game, and I was 100% sure that “_O_KI” was going to be a Greek word.

Funnily enough, ENISLE (a word I had definitely never seen, let alone heard) came to me fairly quickly…
This puzzle was absolutely wizard. Quite spiffing, really.

"“fly” was a high compliment in the 1980s."

OMG not unless you were completely clueless.
I have no idea if this is a common occurrence and I've just missed it, but man does it feel cool doing a crossword by the Creator of The Far Side. OMGoodness!!!

RUF/FOOTIES held up the solve until I finally replaced with B. I'll not admit to being intimately familiar with Shakespeare, but FOOTIES definitely made sense and I talked myself into RUF as an odd Shakespeare twist. Therein lied the rub.
TIL that “enisle” is a word. Seems particularly apt timing for this vocabulary addition as I’m currently reading Count of Monte Cristo.

I saw the best words of my generation lampooned by crosswords and I'm down with that. A howler.

However, as a proud millennial(plus a snarky Zer plus a cranky Alpha)(What, I can't math generations that way?), I must argue that SHIPPING LANES is incorrect. It's the characters that are being shipped, not the LANES. I doubt Nathan would be interested in that relationship IRL.

"Now don't you tell me you don't remember me 'cause I sure as heckfire remember you. Ned ... Nickerson. Needlenose Ned? Ned the Head? C'mon, buddy. Case Western High. I did the whistling belly-button trick at the high school talent show? Bing."

Split the difference of my best and average times. So, a better than average experience, all around. I guess my age might have something to do with it. Finally, a puzzle for geezers! No mention of Charli XCX, how wonderful!
Nice swingin' on the flippity-flop with you all. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grunge_speak
ENISLE??? Seriously??
My favorite clue. “Collectors item”. Brilliant!

Today's clues involve so much trivia and obscure, deeply male slang ("banned body builders, slangily?), I started to feel sick, flipping back and forth from internet to puzzle.  It's not a crime to clue words from the English language!

Wow, what a fun Sunday! I managed to split the difference between my best solving time and my average. I think that's a good indication that the difficulty was spot-on for me.

The last two that fell into place for me were 13D and 104A/106D. I didn't know IRR, so I guessed PARR for the last names of The Incredibles. I had SHOPPING LANES and didn't know IRINA. Fortunately today's column explained 104A, and I finally managed to get SHIPPING LANES. 🤦‍♂️

Looking forward the more from Mr. Larson & Mr. Peterson!

Would have commented enthusiastically in Saturday's comments but didn't finish till this morning. SW was a doozy for me - ironic since I'm currently visiting the Southwest! 5 revisits and 1:29:00 of pure puzzle joy. The whole thing reminded me of puzzles from 20 yrs ago.
Streak's intact, but wouldn't have been bothered at all if that one bested me.
Bring it on, Sunday!
i unfortunately was not able to solve this one without checking my answers, but holy moly! i can definitely appreciate the work that went into this one. loved the theme!
TIL the words AVARICE, ENISLE, AND FILCH. Although I still don’t get what IRR is relative to bargain bin? Irregular? Internal rate of return?
What a pleasant puzzle and clever theme!! Never know what to expect after Saturday and Wednesday’s puzzles. A few difficult clues but doable
89 Down: Still using apostrophes for plurals? tsk tsk

Shipping lanes must go down as one of the most tortured clues of all time. I didn't see the need for the bracketed additions to the clues it just made me think there was something else going on. I also didn't enjoy enisle and irr as answers

Whew. I'll give that a star as one of the oddest puzzles I can remember. Still don't entirely grasp how some of the clues are working. Maybe it's because I'm a boomer sooner. No big deal. Puzzle find today, perhaps somewhat appropriate. A Tuesday from December 26, 2000 by Gene Newman. Three theme answers, each of them clued as "Some 60-across" and then "More 60 across" and then "Still more 60-across." Those answers: GOFLYAKITE DONTBOTHERME LEAVEMEALONE And then - 60 across clue and answer: "Theme (and genre) of this puzzle" CROSSWORDS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/26/2000&g=18&d=A I'm done. ...

I'm not sure the generational designations were always helpful or even correct in these clues. I'm GenX, and for most of the answers, the generational slang terms came to me first, and then I had to figure out the second parts of the answers that went with them. But I think it's more to do with what circles you run in than when you were born. I probably hang out on REDDIT too much.

I sense an additional theme to this puzzle.  The boss is the TOPBANANA. "Kids Make Nutritious Meals." A hottie is a SNACK. 

Speaking of which, I don't have a problem with that last one. Why do some of us have the urge to NIBBLE on kitty cat ears or baby toes? And why does my cat go from enjoying being petted to suddenly chomping on my hand and drooling all over my lap? We often use food-related words to describe those we find overwhelmingly cute. Sweetie pie. Honey. Cookie. Cupcake. And now, SNACK for people we find romantically attractive.

To me, referring to someone as a snack isn't necessarily objectifying *them* (although it could be) but more a way to describe the way *you* feel around them... the way your neurological system responds. That said, it's clear from the comments that not everyone has those feelings, or at least y'all have more self-control than I do.

And now, I need to go break into the bag of Halloween candy I was saving for the 31st.

NOM.
ENISLE !? That's one that would have never occurred to me especially as I'm not sure I've ever encountered it before.
A lot of things I didn't know, but very approachable. Got a kick at various points of the solve. For instance, getting the covetousness gave me the greed, which gave me the theft.
I can't wrap my head around the stan laurel as being an GenZ slang. It can't be related to the early comedic duo, that's pre-boomer. How would GenZers know this?
Fast, fun and easy solve.  I needed that today!
Sorry if this is obvious, but why is PEE "head of production"?
Didn't Gary Larson do satirical cartoons in the past?

I'm Gen X (1970) and don't think I've ever described something as "FLY", but I've definitely used "CHILL".  

As with several other commenters, ENISLE is a new-to-me word, which I will now file in the "crosswordese" section of my brain.

Enjoyable puzzle, regardless.

I’m sorry but I’m truly disgusted at the inclusion of “Snack”. Don’t we women have enough to deal with right now without being denigrated that way in the NY Times? And don’t tell me “hotties” could refer to a man too cause we all know that not how it’s commonly used.

SNACKCOUNTER, like, gag me with a spoon... ewwww! Totally grody to the max! I checked it out and don't dispute its existence but again I say, ewwwww! 

It reminds me of a time someone said, "Aw, that baby's so cute I just want to get a spoon and scoop her up." Ewwwwwww!!!! Stop! 

Okay, okay, aside from my extreme aversion to the idea of considering humans as edible treats, I enjoyed the puzzle! Went very smoothly along and a simple but cute theme! I actually finished in half my average time to make up for how long Saturday's fun but hard puzzle took me. Har!

However, I don't understand IRR at 13D—can anyone, or everyone, enlighten me?
Perhaps the only puzzle I enjoyed this week and I didn't even care much for the theme.

I just finished reading through the comments while trying to imagine a movie where the Lanes' characters get shipped. Sequel to The Birdcage where Diane Lane takes over for Dianne Wiest and the (very sadly) widowed grandparents spar over making their grandkids nutrious meals? Take my money!

(And yes, I'm well aware of the most obvious hurdle. Weirder "ships" have sailed.)

Okay - one of the most unusual puzzles I've come across. A Thursday from November 16, 2017 by Alex Eylar. Some examples: 17a "See 58-across." answer: TAUTOLOGY 58A "See 17-across." answer: TAUTOLOGY 36A "See 66 across" - But... there is no 66 across, so the answer to 36a is: AWILDGOOSECHASE 25a "See 25-across" RECURSION 46A "See ??-Across " AMBIGUITY Here's that link if you want to go see it: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/16/2017&g=46&d=A ...
Really fun puzzle! Thanks, Gary and Doug!
Thank you for including the link to Smoky & Bill's story (72d).  It made my day.  Take a moment and enjoy ~
I wonder why this article is not appearing on the main Wordplay column page? I kept waiting for it and thinking it was delayed... https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/daily-crossword-column
I remember, back in the 1980's, I used to visit the brick-n-mortar nislery, but now, I just go online and enisle.

"What’s in the parentheses is one of four living generations: baby boomers (23-, 116-Across), Gen X (32-, 71-Across), millennial (48-, 104-Across) and Gen Z (68-, 87-Across)."

Uh, let's not forget the "silent generation" (born between ~ 1928 and 1945), e.g., Joe Biden et al.  They're not all dead (yet)!

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

I couldn't figure out the top right today, a lot of proper nouns in areas I'd never heard of.

But 46D might be my favorite crossword clue ever with AMBIGUITY.  And the generational slang theme feels like a response to criticism about having slang clues only people under 20 would know.
Seems pretty crazy to write a "tricky clues" section with things like "KEN DOLL" and "YORKIE" but then act like the word "ENISTLE" was one of the easy ones.
Absolutely wild to call Portia the "heroine" of The Merchant of Venice

Fun puzzle. It took me a couple of looks to understand ENISLE. At first I wondered if it was a reddish color before I got it the fact that it meant actively marooned. I was surprised I made it almost all the way through before running into that section.

Didn't enjoy this one.

I got the theme but the answers felt forced or obscure.

Feels overbaked, like someone really clever made it too clever to be fun. Just a slog of Thursday calibur wordplay and trivias.

Maybe it's me but I'm finding the past week or two way less enjoyable.
STAN is definitely a millennial term; not Gen Z.
We solved it, but we didn't enjoy it. Sort of shocked to see so many positive comments. felt like a slog of fil

TEENIE (99 across) and EENSY (126 across) as fill in the same puzzle both intersecting with ENISLE? Why does TEENIE end with IE but EENSY with Y other than to make the fill work? This was the last part of the puzzle I got due to originally thinking 126 across couldn’t possibly be EENSY after TEENIE already worked for 99 across. 

OK puzzle otherwise, I understand the theme, but other than the first part of each theme clue being generational slang there is nothing linking the answers together (what does Stan Laurel have to do with Split Second?, etc.) although I hesitate to be too critical because I will never even attempt to construct a crossword.

Mike,
In Munster do you use the Suburban Dictionary?

@Mike

Slang? I've got a ton up in my idiom attic.
@Barry Ancona Urban Dictionary?

Paul,
Mike is in Munster, not Chicago.
@Dutchiris -- Oh, good one!
@Mike Slang is understood by everyone, that’s why it’s called inform-all speech
@Barry Ancona in Munster do they speak Herman?

@Mike

"The cops grabbed Mike by the patois and slung him into jail, where he languaged for days before making bail."

@Mike

108D made me think of you.
Did you read the Today's Theme section of the column? It should ease your head-scratching.

@Cat Lady Margaret

Gonna take the TOP BANANA with you?
OK, Lewis: now provide themers for them!
@Barry Ancona -- Hah!
@Lewis Six seven

@Anita
Right on!

@Robco

Not new to me BUT it did trip me up as I initially had CREME.
@HeathieJ irregular, hence lower priced.

@HeathieJ 
IRRegular items aka factory seconds are often sold as is at a discount

Ahh, thanks Greg and Hallie!  ☺️ I looked it up and was only finding internal rate of return. 

Guess I don't go thrifting enough.
@HeathieJ. We have ENVY and AVARICE. Are getting lust here?
@HeathieJ. And when I think about it…with the food images don’t we also have greed?

Patrick J.,
Gluttony?

@HeathieJ
Interesting that 49D kind of fits right into this discussion, in an ambiguous kind of way.
@HeathieJ I’m with you on SNACK. It made me cringe a bit.

@HeathieJ

I understand your squeamishness about SNACK, but I got to thinking and realized that I sometimes tell my wife she looks delicious, which is much the same thing.  She doesn’t seem offended (and trust me, she’d let me know if she was!).
@Barry Ancona.  Yeah, lazy typing on my part, sloth?

@HeathieJ

I think they should have their ears boxed!
@HeathieJ I'm totally with you.  It seemed so sexist to me that I began to think I was misinterpreting it.  Perhaps by "hotties," they meant hot appetizers?

@Patrick J.

After Chekhov, I unfortunately had SHI_ _ING. What saved me was changing tossing a hat to tossing a CAP.

@Leontion

I had trouble in the SW corner as a whole, so I was very excited to figure out “big kahuna”… until I wasn’t. That was a bit of a time waster. I also plugged in “AYE aye” at first, but recognized that error pretty quickly. Same mistakes, different outcomes!
@Leontion BIG KAHUNA messed me up for the longest time until I fixed it with the guidance of the crosses in that area.
@Leontion I also tried Big Kahuna!

@dutchiris I like your phrasing 'victory snaps'

"The top half went a little fast but got more interesting as I went down." 

SP,
Agree! Most of the fill clues at the top of the puzzle felt like Monday to me; Wednesday kicked in later.

SP,
If "snack" is not gender-specific, what is in bad taste about using it? Or would you also not want to see "hotties" in the grid?

@Barry Ancona

It’s not about being gender specific, it’s about the implication that the person has no value except for their sexual attractiveness and can be used and thrown away. Hottie is just another term (admittedly a bit crass, but still) for a beautiful person. if I overheard someone call me a hottie, I would not be offended. If they called me a snack, even as a male, I would be. I’m not saying ban it or anything, I’m not for censorship, just wanted to hear other peoples’ reactions. I will say if I personally had come up with this theme and had that as my last themer, I would either have found another option or not submitted it. And again most of the time I’m not bothered by this sort of thing, so I’m just trying to gauge why I have this reaction and whether other people felt the same.

SP,
I don't read "snack" as a throwaway any more than I would read "hottie" as a throwaway or read "beauty" as a throwaway. That's just me.
@SP  Agree with you, it’s a bit demeaning for either sex.

@SP 

Since the theme is observing generational slang, with no advocacy implied, I think we can cut the creators some slack. If there's an issue it would be the word 'hottie' since this is written from creators' pov vs 'snack' which is observed usage, but here again I'd say give them a pass.

Here's the Cambridge Dictionary's take on the slang meaning of 'snack' (which tbh I had never encountered before)

'Snack: slang

an attractive person:

'Vinny is such a snack.'

I'm stuck between wanting to look like a snack and eating a snack.'

@SP

I appreciate the solidarity!!  Not that anyone's commenting on my post about this, which is fine...  but I will say that I  agree with everything you're saying. I mean, calling another human that you find attractive a snack is just creepy and crass to me. It's like there's not even human, they're just something to be consumed for your pleasure. Like how I enjoyed some ruffles and onion dip over at my neighbor friend's house tonight... 

Maybe I'm just too visual about these things, I do also hate the phrase picking your brain, but treating humans with that crass of language is very off-putting.

And I rarely object to any of the sayings of other generations. In most ways, I'm pretty chill about these sorts of things. 

And I'm 100% against any sort of censorship but that means I get to say how I feel about this phrasing....  I guess I'm just a weirdo who is not a fan of talking about you know eating other people.......... I think it's weird. Very, very very, weird and demeaning.

@SP I agree with you. SNACK seemed so out of tune that I avoided it for a long time, thinking there’s no way the editors would let such a demeaning term through. It definitely hit me in the “eww” spot.

@SP

Seems similar to eye candy or arm candy. A bit risqué? but not necessarily in bad taste.

@SP It struck me as icky. However, it’s possible that my Gen Z son would roll his eyes as my reaction. Again. It’s also possible that the NYT editorial staff includes, or consulted with, some from that generation before deciding to include it. 

I’ll still call it icky but I accept that it may not have been used in a demeaning way. Mr. Smartypants tells me it’s like calling someone yummy,  which also sounds icky to me.

@SP Boomer here, so SNACK isn't really in my lexicon. For me, the term is objectifying but not demeaning. I'm past the age where I find that offensive, I think it's just amusing. 

But thinking further, I don't find words to be offensive themselves (except for obvious exceptions), more the intent behind the words and how they are expressed. I guarantee you that I could completely creep you out with very benign words, but delivered in an excessively lascivious manner! Not going to do that, though, but I could. On the other hand, our language has enough AMBIGUITY that very naughty words can be said in an innocent way and be super funny. Delivery and intent is key.

@SP
Both hottie and snack seem unpleasant to me, and I'm too old to have never heard of them.

SP,
If the newer term "snack" seems too transient, but you don't mind the idea of a "meal," how do rate the somewhat dated "dish?"

@SP
While I understand your objections, the word doesn’t strike me in the same way. To me, calling someone a “snack” doesn’t necessarily imply that they have no value, or are likely to be discarded. It means they are irresistible. While a meal is something a good upbringing says you need and should have, a snack is something you *want*, even if it may not be good for you. It’s simply sweet and enticing. It may not be in the best taste to talk about consuming someone, but since the term is lighthearted and not literal, it doesn’t bother me at all. (Boomer/GenX cusp here, BTW.)

@Barry Ancona
I read 'snack' here as precisely equivalent to 'arm candy'. I don't recall seeing that phrase here; has it appeared and, if so, did it generate any response like this?

@Barry Ancona

For some reason I don’t mind “dish” as much. As I said it’s not the equating of sex with food that bugged me, that has a long and storied history and can even be romantic in the right context. It was the snack portion (pun intended).

@kkseattle

I appreciate everyone’s input pro and con but I think you get the gold star for most convincing rebuttal (and also Nora). No I don’t have the same visceral reaction to “eye candy” for some reason, which is inconsistent. It’s equally demeaning as “snack” and also has the connotation of using them only for their sexual attractiveness. The only difference is that I see the former as mainly for looking at and the latter for carnal purposes. But that probably comes from being from my generation and getting used to the term. I suspect that people saying “snack” think of it exactly the same way. So, everyone, although I won’t be using the term any time soon I officially withdraw my objection as to its appropriateness. Thanks for engaging me on this—I try to have an open mind.

@SBK

It has! In fact, it just appeared this month on 10/6. The clue was "Good-looking companion on the red carpet, say." I don't know if it generated a similar response... I'm not inclined to scroll through the comments to find out

@SP

Well, the solidarity was fun while it lasted! Hahaha! 😂

I have a rather open mind, myself, which, in this case, leads me to people can say what they want to say and I get to feel the way I feel about it. And I just can't get over the huge eww factor or seeing it as incredibly demeaning, as I do some of the other examples listed by other commenters. And that's okay. I'm not trying to censor anyone... But if someone says something like it to me I will have a snarky but funny reply. 

I think I might be a bit past the age of being called a snack though, so we're all probably safe there. 😂

@HeathieJ

Well I still have the Eww factor and always will, I’m just  convinced that it’s more a peculiar reaction by me than the general consensus.

@SP

To me, "eye candy" doesn't imply consuming, but feasting one's eyes. "Snack" to me implied consuming when I saw it in the grid and I did have a moment of eww, while realizing it might not have the same connotation to younger folks.

I also have the reaction when someone says they'd like to eat a baby up with a spoon. Or a stranger at a party saying that to me, which actually happened in my distant past.

There is something similar when overhearing someone at a party rating the attractiveness of others. I don't mean saying that someone looks delicious (which I have certainly said), I mean ranking people on a scale. 

It's being treated as something to consume and be done with. An experience I suspect many of us have had.

So I grant you the validity of your eww!
@HeathieJ I dislike the phrase "no brainer" for exactly the same reason. I immediately visualise an empty skull!

@SP
I mostly agree.  Maybe it's in the same genus as 'Hey, that fill-in-the-blank is a tall glass of water, eh?'

@Dan Solovay

As I recall from my waiting days, credit card tips are for sure taxable....  Cash are, um, debatable. I always preferred cash tip...
@Dan Solovay I took tips to mean insider trading.

@HeathieJ

Yeah, I always used to leave cash tips to give the beleaguered waitstaff the option to report or not.  Having worked in restaurants, I was well aware of the puny wages.  But with the new rules it’s less important to do so because a portion of tip income is no longer taxable.

@HeathieJ

The tax code says all tips are taxable (actually all income is taxable unless specifically excluded).  The ones that come in cash are taxable but easier to hide from the taxman.  

The tax law recently changed and now exempts some tips.

Jerry,

STAN is generational slang term for an ardent fan. We're all supposed to know a LAUREL is recognition. That fills the themer. The only question is whether everyone will know why STAN LAUREL is funny.

@Jerry,
A "Stan" is a term for an obsessed fan.  It comes from a collaboration song by Eminem and Dido. In the verses, Eminem describes a series of letters from a fan whose correspondence is becoming more and more unhealthy, interspersed with choruses from Dido's song "Thank You", in which she describes the comfort a good relationship can bring in troubled time.   It ends with Eminem writing the fan back, trying to comfort him.
The song is 25 years old, but the term has stuck.
Btw, the end parts of the thematic answers are not connected in meaning to the slang parts at the beginning.  It's that the slang plus the end part together create a third, quite well-known reference.
@Jerry - I know what STAN means in the context of this puzzle, but I was sorry they didn't include Oliver Hardy somewhere.
@Jerry yeah "stan" predates gen z, and "shipping" predates millennials. Slang is hard to track down... But these ones can easily be found as older than their listed gens so it was a little iffy.

jennie,
Fine in a newspaper for my family, which has more guys who are not male than are (Did you know women are guys now too?).

@Meryl S. It's not a denigrating term. It just means an attractive person. It's a lighthearted, tongue in cheek kind of term. And it's probably used more often for men, actually. Certainly I've usually seen it for attractive male celebrities more than anything else. 

I don't know who these people getting upset at an entirely innocuous Internet-ism is, but as a woman of reproductive age, there are very real problems that we face and this isn't one of them.

@jennie, there is nothing inappropriate about the words you object to in your comment. Mons simply means "mound", in this case, the actual name of a volcano. Even in the sense you take offense at it's just a mound, and a body part. Maybe untwist your knickers?

@Meryl S.
What you can do to help stop the belittling of women is don't apologize for your opinions. Don't lead with "I'm sorry". Do you ever hear anyone who is taken seriously do that?

@Meryl S.would you have the same objection if someone were called a “feast for the eyes”? This is more or less how “snack” is used by some.

Any of these could be used to objectify someone, but that doesn’t make them inherently bad in any context. 

If NYT removed any word that anyone ever found insulting, it would deny us a lot of excellent puzzles. There are absolutely words that shouldn’t be used, but this isn’t one of them.

I think when we stop giving people the benefit of the doubt and see the worst in everything, we also stop learning.
